In the game, you play as an unnamed adventurer/trader, that sets forth to do one thing, become the Master Trader of the known universe/galaxy. One of the first missions is to find some chick that will give you a million credits on loan in order for you to buy a ship and start trading. You have a deadline when to get the million credits needed, and this formula repeats itself several times throughout the game, so much so that even the multiplayer is basically only that. In order to GET the million credits, you have to buy some commodities on Earth, and go to the Moon (which is just clicking a button) and selling your merchandise. Or you can do contracts. Space Trader Merchant Marine is that strange situation where two very different genres have been combined together in the hope of hitting that once in a lifetime combination that everybody agrees is pure genius, like Vampires and Teenagers, or Ninjas and Cheerleaders. Space Trader doesn't quite hit that special recipe however.

Space Trader is a combination of a numbers trading simulator and a first person shooter and by far and large the biggest problem is that playing the game you have trouble telling which of these two aspects feel the most tacked on.

The trading part of the game is simple enough. You travel between various planets in the solar system, each planet has a a few merchants each selling a few goods. You buy as much as your bank account and cargo space will allow and then travel to the next world. Space Trader has no real in game economy however and everything is decided by the almighty Random Number Generator. The challenge of choosing which products to buy is virtually non-existent as all items for sale lists how below normal market value they are next to their name. There is also a legal/non-legal system in place however it has no real effect in game making the actual buying and selling of products extremely dull and predictable.

You explore the various locations on foot, in a first person shooter aspect. The various trade hubs allow you run around a small area, collecting various sellable items littered about the place, trade with the local merchants and take on a number of missions. reviewText:
Presentation
Steam Sales are always a great way to buy more games than you'll ever be able to play, but between all the big purchases you will often find some random games to keep you busy when there's nothing else; Space Trader: Merchant Marine is exactly that kind of game, but unlike most small, indie games this one managed somehow to keep me around more than it should have, just because at its core, it's an addictive experience. The premise of the game is simple: you are a new trader trying to find your way in this business and since you don't own a ship yet you need to find someone who is willing to give you one. What follows is a simple story and you will see the little twists coming from miles away, but even with that in mind, the missing excitement of what's going to happen next isn't the thing that will keep you around. The campaign has only five chapters and once you understand the mechanics of the game you will have no problem making millions from trading food stamps, oil or even organs. This game simulates the stocks trades perfectly, following the same: buy low, sell high premise, and even though at first it may be hard to figure out how to make all those millions, once you get the idea, it will be only profit for you from that point on. There's no real reward for doing this except the fact that once you reach a goal you will advance to the next chapter and start all over, trading between different planets, but that little sense of advancement is what will keep you playing.
Rating: 5.5

Gameplay
The gameplay in Space Trader is pretty straight forward: you start on a planet and you have to buy commodities that will bring a profit and travel to another planet to sell them at a higher price, keeping a constant watch on the time limit that each mission has, calculating the profit per shipment and the travel time in order to choose the best option. Finding good deals is easy since those always have a gold star indicating that you should buy them, so eventually it becomes just a matter of having enough money in your pocket or enough cargo space, and your only enemy becomes the time as you carefully have to choose where to sell the stuff you just bought. You can make money by taking bounty missions from bartenders or by completing small tasks for different people, so it's always a good idea to talk with everybody because you might find out some interesting things or take on some missions that will give you some extra cash. The shooting mechanic feels old, but that's probably why it feels so addictive at the same time, as you will most likely instantly connect the dots between those shooting sequences and games like Doom, and even though all those bounty missions will get boring pretty soon as each map looks and feels the same and there are only two to three different types of enemies plus the target that you're supposed to assassinate, it is a good distraction from the boring buy and sell mechanic that the game generally delivers.
Rating: 6

Graphics
If you look at this game you will assume it was released in the early 2000's because it looks like it was made a generation ago; from the simple and stiff characters to the environments everything looks pretty bad and the repetitive level design doesn't help either. By the end of the game you will know every corner of each planet, you will start to love a certain section for how easy it is to complete a combat mission and you will hate another for how difficult it is.
Rating: 5

Audio
The sound in this game ain't exactly bad, but it's simply mediocre at best. The voice acting is horrible, but the soundtrack manages to save it sometimes, especially in the heat of a battle, but otherwise there is nothing that stands out, it simply gets boring as you will end up ignoring the other characters or laugh at how bad they sound no matter the serious, story essential thing they just said. There are intentional comic lines too, such as the robot that answers by saying WTF, but those only make the entire thing feel worse, as the game is undecided between trying to be serious and making fun of itself.
Rating: 5

Extras
After completing the main campaign you can also try the challenge mode that offers three extra missions that are pretty easy to complete and the only real challenge comes when you try to get the achievements, and if you're into that the game can get interesting and it has even some decent replay value as you can spend up to 18 hours struggling to complete everything. It's also supposed to have a multiplayer mode, which puts you and a friend in a race to get the most cash from those challenge missions, but after an hour of banging my head against the wall I couldn't figure out a way of making it work.
Rating: 5

Verdict
When a game is getting such a low score no one would actually recommend buying it, but in this case I'll make an exception: you should give it a try if it's on sale and you can get it for less than an euro, as for that amount of money it will keep you busy more than enough to justify the purchase. It is in no way a great game, one that you will remember after leaving it aside, but as long as you play it you will be entertained simply because it's so stupid it becomes like a good parody.
Rating Overall: 5.3

reviewText:
Okay.

Yes, it's an 'old' game from five years ago, so you can argue that the graphics shouldn't be expected to be cutting edge...but the modelling and textures and the like look considerably WORSE than Unreal - a game that came out _ten_years_before_ Space Trader: Merchant Marine.

I admit that I'm a fan of Elite-style games: a hybrid of space flight/combat and trading simulation - WC:Privateer, X: Beyond the Frontier, Freelancer, Frontier: Elite II, etc.

...this is NOT that type of hybrid, despite the implication of the title.

This game tries to weld FPS and trading together, and does NOT do a very good job with EITHER.

1) The trading is simplistic, static and easily exploited.
For each 'sector', there are a small handful of commodities, only a similar number of bases/trading hubs to buy and sell the same at, so you could probably chart out all the prices on a Post-It™ note...or even commit the best 'trading routes' to even a dodgy, old and  forgetful memory.

And you won't have to worry about breaking the economy with your efforts - apparently each base has such large demands and supplies of EVERY commodity that even a huge shipment moved by yourself has NO effect on prices on either end of your run.  Your only restriction to making money is finding the best profit margin, and the size of your cargo hold (& working capital).

...but hey; you don't even really need to worry about trading to get up these thinly-justified goals for earning - a) you can usually find piles of items just sitting in nooks and corners on the trading hub maps, which you can then sell to collectors for a decent starting stake, b) you can also pick up a considerable amount of cash from doing the bounty (aka FPS) missions - not always from the up-front wages of that, but from looting commodities from the 'hideout' of whatever low-life you're supposed to assassinate.

2) As others have said, the FPS is similarly unchallenging - the maps are limited in quantity and variety, the 'power ups' are uninspired (and ephemeral), and the opposing AI is laughable, resulting in no point in any gameplay strategy apart from sneaking quickly to a good vantage point and then sniping everyone just aimlessly standing around.

As such, you have two poor component-games, that barely feel like they should even belong together; the overall story is threadbare and challenges even the most credulous willing suspension of disbelief.

Normally, I have very low standards to play a game (gfx, music, v/o, story, etc.) but this game managed to sink below even those unchallenging requirements.

Do not even bother with this on a steam sale - the ONLY reasonable justification I could say for buying this game would be to bump up your XP from sheer quantity of game-ownership, and even then, a heavy discount would be necessary.

...but even so, I would under NO account EVER suggest you PLAY this 'game'...

reviewText:
The basic principle in this game is: buy low, sell high. Unfortunately there aren't that many things to buy and sell, but nevertheless the concept of trading and traveling between space stations is quite well implemented and works. This part is relatively easy, and once you get the hang of the game you'll see the numbers in your bank account grow exponentially. If you need some extra cash you can try your hand at bountyhunting, which teleports you to one of a series of FPS arenas where you get to shoot people. Very basic but enjoyable while it lasts.

The biggest annoyance I found in this game is the lack of a sandbox / open-ended mode. The game is divided up into missions, guiding you through the stages of development for your very own space trading enterprise, but after each mission you basically start over.

Other than that, this game is a lot of fun to play and although it won't be able to keep your attention forever (it can get a bit repetitive over time) it is a fun little game and a great timekiller if you have nothing to do for a couple of hours. The price is already fairly low, and if you can get this game in a sale like I did you basically just can't go wrong.

There's no real reward for doing this except the fact that once you reach a goal you will advance to the next chapter and start all over, trading between different planets, but that little sense of advancement is what will keep you playing.
Rating: 5.5

Gameplay
The gameplay in Space Trader is pretty straight forward: you start on a planet and you have to buy commodities that will bring a profit and travel to another planet to sell them at a higher price, keeping a constant watch on the time limit that each mission has, calculating the profit per shipment and the travel time in order to choose the best option. Finding good deals is easy since those always have a gold star indicating that you should buy them, so eventually it becomes just a matter of having enough money in your pocket or enough cargo space, and your only enemy becomes the time as you carefully have to choose where to sell the stuff you just bought. You can make money by taking bounty missions from bartenders or by completing small tasks for different people, so it's always a good idea to talk with everybody because you might find out some interesting things or take on some missions that will give you some extra cash. The shooting mechanic feels old, but that's probably why it feels so addictive at the same time, as you will most likely instantly connect the dots between those shooting sequences and games like Doom, and even though all those bounty missions will get boring pretty soon as each map looks and feels the same and there are only two to three different types of enemies plus the target that you're supposed to assassinate, it is a good distraction from the boring buy and sell mechanic that the game generally delivers.
Rating: 6

Graphics
If you look at this game you will assume it was released in the early 2000's because it looks like it was made a generation ago; from the simple and stiff characters to the environments everything looks pretty bad and the repetitive level design doesn't help either. By the end of the game you will know every corner of each planet, you will start to love a certain section for how easy it is to complete a combat mission and you will hate another for how difficult it is.
Rating: 5

Audio
The sound in this game ain't exactly bad, but it's simply mediocre at best. The voice acting is horrible, but the soundtrack manages to save it sometimes, especially in the heat of a battle, but otherwise there is nothing that stands out, it simply gets boring as you will end up ignoring the other characters or laugh at how bad they sound no matter the serious, story essential thing they just said. There are intentional comic lines too, such as the robot that answers by saying WTF, but those only make the entire thing feel worse, as the game is undecided between trying to be serious and making fun of itself.
Rating: 5

Extras
After completing the main campaign you can also try the challenge mode that offers three extra missions that are pretty easy to complete and the only real challenge comes when you try to get the achievements, and if you're into that the game can get interesting and it has even some decent replay value as you can spend up to 18 hours struggling to complete everything. It's also supposed to have a multiplayer mode, which puts you and a friend in a race to get the most cash from those challenge missions, but after an hour of banging my head against the wall I couldn't figure out a way of making it work.
Rating: 5

Verdict
When a game is getting such a low score no one would actually recommend buying it, but in this case I'll make an exception: you should give it a try if it's on sale and you can get it for less than an euro, as for that amount of money it will keep you busy more than enough to justify the purchase. It is in no way a great game, one that you will remember after leaving it aside, but as long as you play it you will be entertained simply because it's so stupid it becomes like a good parody.
Rating Overall: 5.3

reviewText:
Space Trader: Merchant Marine is a bipolar game.  On the one hand, it tries to capture gamer interest as a commodities trading game, where you would buy and sell different commodities seeking to make a profit.  Yet, the game developers seem to realize the major flaw with this game--it gets boring quickly.  So they made a hackneyed attempt to spruce it up by adding a bulky, vastly inferior First Person Shooter component with graphics that are reminiscent of Doom.  I think the developers should have focused solely on the trading aspect, because consumers do realize the commodity trading simulation is the major draw of this game, and certainly not the FPS aspect.

How would I improve the commodity trading aspect?  I would offer unlockable merchants when certain conditions are met (i.e. a million dollars worth of legit inventory, or x number of cargo holds added to your ship), or create another category of goods.  What about the trader's personal reputation? What if the trader's reputation changes over time, as he deals in certain types of goods, and that influences pricing of wares from the NPC merchants?  These are some simple ways to spice up the trading simulation, and I'm sure the game developers could implement these additions quite easily.

As it stands now, the game will capture your interest only until you get bored and tired of the commodity trading aspect.  How long will depend on personal tastes.

reviewText: I bought this game at the low price of $0.50, and I can honestly say it is worth the asking price of $4.99. The game is graphically inferior and at time, even comedic to the point of leaving your PC because a character looks so much like a potato you can't stop laughing. The voice acting is hilariously bad, especially the mechanic which comes into the game later in the plot (what 'ave you broken today). However bad some of the features in this game are, it does offer a unique and addictive experience in terms of game play. Buy low, sell high. This is what you need to remember as a merchant marine, although it's never usually so simple, buying any item is a risk to your bank account, a gamble even. But the payoff for a successful trade is extremely satisfying considering it's just words on the screen. Besides the addictive and risky trading, some NPC's will offer side quests in the form of assassinations for the most part. These will play out like a good old match of Quake 3 Arena, with fast paced combat, futuristic weapons and contained, yet large areas. Power ups and shields lay around the arena for the player to pick up and any enemy can be a serious threat if not taken care of quickly. In short, this game is a fun little title, worth your time, and considering how often it is on special for under $1, there's no real reason for you to not own it.

reviewText:
|   11240 | Space Trader is a interesting idea of a indie game, travel around the galaxy and make profit, too bad the execution is not as well done, still a fun game for a few hours.
In this game you are a nameless trader who just got the license to trade, but all you need is a ship, and so across 5 chapters you get to become the master traders dealing with corrupt officers, betrayals, and trade wars.
The graphics are somewhat ok for a indiegame and the music is not bad but there's only 2-3 songs at all.
The trade mechanics is very simple you buy stuff and go sell it at another planet for profit studying random events like drug busts making drug kind of items sell for higher and etc, but if this was a real trade game you would be able to negotiate for a better profit, you can't in this game.
You can also partake in bounties, or fight the guards scanning your ship for illegal stuff in a simple fps kind of like unreal tournament, but not even close to good, still it does it's job.
For 5 dollars this game is maybe worth it if you ran out of stuff to play, but you're probably better off buying it during a sale or bundle for less than a dollar.
